1. Introduction and Motivation

Vector spaces are fundamental structures in mathematics that find applications in many fields such as physics, computer science, and engineering. They form the basis for linear algebra and are essential for understanding many mathematical concepts.

What is a Vector Space?

A vector space is a set of objects (vectors) that can be added together and multiplied by scalars, while satisfying certain rules.

2. Definition and Axioms

Formal Definition

A vector space V over a field K (e.g., ‚Ñù or ‚ÑÇ) is a set with two operations:

  1. Associativity: u + (v + w) = (u + v) + w
  2. Commutativity: u + v = v + u

3. Examples of Vector Spaces

‚Ñù¬≤ (2-dimensional real vector space)

The ‚Ñù¬≤ consists of all ordered pairs of real numbers:

$$\mathbb{R}^2 = \{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \mid x,y \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

Example of vector addition:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$$

Example of scalar multiplication:

$$2 \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$$

‚Ñù¬≥ (3-dimensional real vector space)

The ‚Ñù¬≥ consists of all ordered triples of real numbers:

$$\mathbb{R}^3 = \{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} \mid x,y,z \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

Example of vector addition:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 5 \\ 6 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ 7 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$$

Example of scalar multiplication:

$$3 \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 3 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$$

Polynomial Space

The set of all polynomials of degree ‚â§ n forms a vector space:

$$P_n = \{a_0 + a_1x + a_2x^2 + ... + a_nx^n \mid a_i \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

Example of polynomial addition:

$$(1 + 2x + 3x^2) + (2 + 3x + 4x^2) = 3 + 5x + 7x^2$$

Example of scalar multiplication:

$$2 \cdot (1 + x + x^2) = 2 + 2x + 2x^2$$

Matrix Space

The set of all m√ón matrices forms a vector space:

$$M_{m,n} = \{A = (a_{ij}) \mid a_{ij} \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

Example of matrix addition:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 & 8 \\ 10 & 12 \end{pmatrix}$$

Example of scalar multiplication:

$$2 \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 4 \\ 6 & 8 \end{pmatrix}$$

4. Subspaces

Definition

A subspace U of a vector space V is a subset of V that is itself a vector space.

Criteria for Subspaces

  2. ‚àÄ u,v ‚àà U : u + v ‚àà U

Examples of Subspaces

1. The x-axis is a subspace of ‚Ñù¬≤:

$$U = \{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \mid x \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

2. The set of all polynomials of degree ‚â§ 2 is a subspace of the polynomial space:

$$U = \{a_0 + a_1x + a_2x^2 \mid a_i \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

3. The set of all symmetric 2√ó2 matrices is a subspace of the matrix space:

$$U = \{\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ b & c \end{pmatrix} \mid a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

5. Linear Independence

Definition

Vectors v‚ÇÅ, v‚ÇÇ, ..., v‚Çô are called linearly independent if the equation:

$$\alpha_1 v_1 + \alpha_2 v_2 + ... + \alpha_n v_n = 0$$

has only the trivial solution Œ±‚ÇÅ = Œ±‚ÇÇ = ... = Œ±‚Çô = 0.

Examples of Linear Independence

1. The vectors (1,0) and (0,1) are linearly independent in ‚Ñù¬≤:

$$\alpha_1\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + \alpha_2\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \Rightarrow \alpha_1 = \alpha_2 = 0$$

2. The vectors (1,2,3), (4,5,6), and (7,8,9) are linearly dependent in ‚Ñù¬≥:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 8 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = 2\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 5 \\ 6 \end{pmatrix}$$

3. The polynomials 1, x, x¬≤ are linearly independent in the polynomial space:

$$\alpha_1 \cdot 1 + \alpha_2 \cdot x + \alpha_3 \cdot x^2 = 0 \Rightarrow \alpha_1 = \alpha_2 = \alpha_3 = 0$$

6. Basis and Dimension

Basis

A basis of a vector space V is a set of linearly independent vectors that span V.

Dimension

The dimension of a vector space is the number of vectors in a basis.

Examples of Bases

1. Standard basis of ‚Ñù¬≤:

$$B = \{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\}$$

2. Standard basis of ‚Ñù¬≥:

$$B = \{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\}$$

3. Basis of the polynomial space P‚ÇÇ:

$$B = \{1, x, x^2\}$$

4. Basis of the space of 2√ó2 matrices:

$$B = \{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\}$$

7. Applications

Geometry

  • Description of points and vectors in space
  • Calculation of distances and angles
  • Transformations (rotation, reflection, scaling)

Physics

  • Description of forces and velocities
  • Electromagnetic fields
  • Quantum mechanical states

Computer Science

  • Computer graphics
  • Machine learning
  • Image processing
  • Data compression

8. Important Theorems

Dimension Theorem

For subspaces U and W of a finite-dimensional vector space V:

$$\dim(U + W) = \dim(U) + \dim(W) - \dim(U \cap W)$$

Basis Extension Theorem

Every linearly independent system of vectors can be extended to a basis.

Example for the Dimension Theorem

Let U and W be two subspaces of ‚Ñù¬≥:

$$U = \{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \mid x,y \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

$$W = \{\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} \mid y,z \in \mathbb{R}\}$$

Then:

$$\dim(U) = 2, \dim(W) = 2, \dim(U \cap W) = 1, \dim(U + W) = 3$$

9. Summary

Vector spaces are fundamental mathematical structures defined by their axioms. They find broad application in various scientific fields and form the basis for many advanced mathematical concepts.

Important Properties:

  • Closure under addition and scalar multiplication
  • Existence of a zero vector
  • Existence of inverse elements
  • Distributivity and associativity

Practical Significance:

  • Description of geometric objects
  • Solution of linear equation systems
  • Modeling of physical phenomena
  • Applications in computer science and engineering
